name: rheum-rhabarbarum
edibility: Cooked leaf stalks (petioles) in pies and puree
leaf-description: Large green leaves up to 2 feet across.  Red petioles which are fleshy and edible when cooked.
poison-symptoms:
TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.  Abdominal cramps, burning of mouth and throat, headache, weakness, nausea and vomiting, coma; may be fatal
Kidney failure (in grazing animals), salivation in dogs/cats. Most toxic parts are leaves and roots.
poison-toxic-principle: Anthraquinone glycosides and soluble oxalates, also possibly calcium oxylate crystals
